newsitem.title: JAPAN: Japan to have more commodity trade inspectors.
newsitem.headline: Japan to have more commodity trade inspectors.

text.p: Japan's Trade Ministry plans to increase the number of commodity trading inspectors to 11 from seven, possibly early next year, in the aftermath of the Sumitomo copper scandal, a ministry official said on Wednesday.
"After the Sumitomo scandal, we felt more inspectors were needed to tighten surveillance," said an official of the Trade Ministry, which supervises local trade houses.

Sumitomo Corp rocked the financial world on June 13 when it announced that it had fired former chief copper trader Yasuo Hamanaka, who it said ran up record losses of $1.8 billion in unauthorised copper trades over a decade.
Separately, the Agriculture Ministry said it plans to assign a specialist to exchange information on commodity trades with overseas regulators.
"There's no plan to increase the number of inspectors on our side. But we're going to assign the specialist post," an official of the ministry said.
